Cast: Wunmi Mosaku, Sope Dirisu, Matt Smith, Cornell John
CriticsConsensus: Featuring genuine scares through every corridor, His House is a terrifying look at the specters of the refugee experience and a stunning feature debut for Remi Weekes.

Cast: Jay Baruchel, Gerard Butler, America Ferrera, Jonah Hill
CriticsConsensus: Boasting dazzling animation, a script with surprising dramatic depth, and thrilling 3-D sequences, How to Train Your Dragon soars.

Cast: Welker White, Reed Birney, Radha Blank, Peter Kim
CriticsConsensus: The Forty-Year-Old Version opens a compelling window into the ebbs and flows of the artist's life -- and announces writer-director-star Radha Blank as a major filmmaking talent with her feature debut.

Cast: Narges Rashidi, Avin Manshadi, Bobby Naderi, Ray Haratian
CriticsConsensus: Under the Shadow deftly blends seemingly disparate genres to deliver an effective chiller with timely themes and thought-provoking social subtext.

MovieTitle: Monty Python and the Holy Grail
Cast: Graham Chapman, John Cleese, Terry Gilliam, Eric Idle
CriticsConsensus: A cult classic as gut-bustingly hilarious as it is blithely ridiculous, Monty Python and the Holy Grail has lost none of its exceedingly silly charm.

Cast: Viola Davis, Chadwick Boseman, Glynn Turman, Colman Domingo
CriticsConsensus: Framed by a pair of powerhouse performances, Ma Rainey's Black Bottom pays affectionate tribute to a blues legend -- and Black culture at large.

Cast: Jeremy Renner, Anthony Mackie, Brian Geraghty, Guy Pearce
CriticsConsensus: A well-acted, intensely shot, action filled war epic, Kathryn Bigelow's The Hurt Locker is thus far the best of the recent dramatizations of the Iraq War.

Cast: Jeff Bridges, Chris Pine, Ben Foster, Gil Birmingham
CriticsConsensus: Hell or High Water offers a solidly crafted, well-acted Western heist thriller that eschews mindless gunplay in favor of confident pacing and full-bodied characters.

Cast: Joanne Rogers, Bill Isler, Hedda Sharapan, Margaret Whitmer
CriticsConsensus: Won't You Be My Neighbor? takes a fittingly patient and honest look at the life and legacy of a television pioneer whose work has enriched generations.

Cast: Eddie Murphy, Wesley Snipes, Kodi Smit-McPhee, Keegan-Michael Key
CriticsConsensus: In dramatizing Rudy Ray Moore's stranger-than-fiction story, Eddie Murphy makes Dolemite Is My Name just as bold, brash, and ultimately hard to resist as its subject.

Cast: Sam Neill, Julian Dennison, Rima Te Wiata, Rachel House
CriticsConsensus: The charmingly offbeat Hunt for the Wilderpeople unites a solid cast, a talented filmmaker, and a poignant, funny, deeply affecting message.

Cast: Carey Mulligan, Jason Clarke, Jason Mitchell, Mary J. Blige
CriticsConsensus: Mudbound offers a well-acted, finely detailed snapshot of American history whose scenes of rural class struggle resonate far beyond their period setting.

Cast: Hakim Faris, Victoire Du Bois, Patrick d'Assumçao, Belek Abdelmalek
CriticsConsensus: Beautifully animated and utterly unique, I Lost My Body takes audiences on a singularly strange journey whose unexpected contours lead to a wholly satisfying destination.

Cast: Bukky Bakray, Ruby Stokes, Sarah Niles, Layo-Christina Akinlude
CriticsConsensus: A fresh, funny coming-of-age story rooted in realistic characters and anchored with a meaningful message, Rocks is as solid as its title suggests.

Cast: Yalitza Aparicio, Marina de Tavira, Marco Graf, Fernando Grediaga
CriticsConsensus: Roma finds writer-director Alfonso Cuarón in complete, enthralling command of his visual craft - and telling the most powerfully personal story of his career.

Cast: Abdou Balde, Aminata Kane, Ibrahima Mbaye, Amadou Mbow
CriticsConsensus: An unpredictable supernatural drama rooted in real-world social commentary, Atlantique suggests a thrillingly bright future for debuting filmmaker Mati Diop.

Cast: Anthony Perkins, Janet Leigh, Vera Miles, John Gavin
CriticsConsensus: Infamous for its shower scene, but immortal for its contribution to the horror genre. Because Psycho was filmed with tact, grace, and art, Hitchcock didn't just create modern horror, he validated it.

MovieTitle: To All the Boys I've Loved Before
Cast: Lana Condor, John Corbett, Noah Centineo, Emilija Baranac
CriticsConsensus: To All the Boys I've Loved Before plays by the teen rom-com rules, but relatable characters and a thoroughly charming cast more than make up for a lack of surprises.

Cast: Graham Chapman, John Cleese, Terry Gilliam, Terry Jones
CriticsConsensus: One of the more cutting-edge films of the 1970s, this religious farce from the classic comedy troupe is as poignant as it is funny and satirical.

Cast: Jay Duplass, Edie Falco, Kaitlyn Dever, Ben Schwartz
CriticsConsensus: Brilliantly brought to life by tenderly empathetic performances from Jay Duplass and Edie Falco, Outside In tells a sobering -- yet thoroughly absorbing -- story.

Cast: Robert De Niro, Al Pacino, Joe Pesci, Anna Paquin
CriticsConsensus: An epic gangster drama that earns its extended runtime, The Irishman finds Martin Scorsese revisiting familiar themes to poignant, funny, and profound effect.

Cast: Scarlett Johansson, Adam Driver, Azhy Robertson, Laura Dern
CriticsConsensus: Observing a splintering union with compassion and expansive grace, the powerfully acted Marriage Story ranks among writer-director Noah Baumbach's best works.

Cast: Maika Monroe, Keir Gilchrist, Daniel Zovatto, Jake Weary
CriticsConsensus: Smart, original, and above all terrifying, It Follows is the rare modern horror film that works on multiple levels -- and leaves a lingering sting.

MovieTitle: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
Cast: Elijah Wood, Ian McKellen, Liv Tyler, Viggo Mortensen
CriticsConsensus: The Two Towers balances spectacular action with emotional storytelling, leaving audiences both wholly satisfied and eager for the final chapter.

Cast: Jason Schwartzman, J.K. Simmons, Rashida Jones, Will Sasso
CriticsConsensus: Beautiful hand-drawn animation and a humorous, heartwarming narrative make Klaus an instant candidate for holiday classic status.

Cast: Clive Owen, Kate Hardie, Alex Kingston, Gina McKee
CriticsConsensus: The writer slumming for human truths and real experience is a common enough story, but this cool-headed and slick thriller provides a gut-churningly compelling backdrop to a look at our darker sides.

Cast: Armie Hammer, Timothée Chalamet, Michael Stuhlbarg, Amira Casar
CriticsConsensus: Call Me by Your Name offers a melancholy, powerfully affecting portrait of first love, empathetically acted by Timothée Chalamet and Armie Hammer.

Cast: Benedict Cumberbatch, Kirsten Dunst, Jesse Plemons, Kodi Smit-McPhee
CriticsConsensus: Brought to life by a stellar ensemble led by Benedict Cumberbatch, The Power of the Dog reaffirms writer-director Jane Campion as one of her generation's finest filmmakers.

Cast: Cate Blanchett, Rooney Mara, Sarah Paulson, Jake Lacy
CriticsConsensus: Shaped by Todd Haynes' deft direction and powered by a strong cast led by Cate Blanchett and Rooney Mara, Carol lives up to its groundbreaking source material.

Cast: Brad Pitt, Jonah Hill, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Robin Wright
CriticsConsensus: Director Bennett Miller, along with Brad Pitt and Jonah Hill, take a niche subject and turn it into a sharp, funny, and touching portrait worthy of baseball lore.

Cast: Olivia Colman, Dakota Johnson, Peter Sarsgaard, Jessie Buckley
CriticsConsensus: A strikingly assured debut for writer-director Maggie Gyllenhaal, The Lost Daughter unites a brilliant cast in service of a daringly ambitious story.

Cast: Karl Urban, Zaris-Angel Hator, Jared Harris, Dan Stevens
CriticsConsensus: An original animated tale that's often as daring as its characters, The Sea Beast sends audiences on a voyage well worth taking.

Cast: Paul Giamatti, Kathryn Hahn, Kayli Carter, Molly Shannon
CriticsConsensus: Private Life uses one couple's bumpy journey to take an affecting look at an easily identifiable - and too rarely dramatized - rite of adult passage.

Cast: Millie Bobby Brown, Henry Cavill, Helena Bonham Carter, David Thewlis
CriticsConsensus: Building on its predecessor with boisterously entertaining flair, Enola Holmes 2 solves the mystery of how to make a satisfying sequel -- and makes it look positively elementary.

Cast: Rod Taylor, Tippi Hedren, Suzanne Pleshette, Jessica Tandy
CriticsConsensus: Proving once again that build-up is the key to suspense, Alfred Hitchcock successfully turned birds into some of the most terrifying villains in horror history.

Cast: Tom Hanks, Catherine Keener, Barkhad Abdi, Barkhad Abdirahman
CriticsConsensus: Smart, powerfully acted, and incredibly intense, Captain Phillips offers filmgoers a Hollywood biopic done right -- and offers Tom Hanks a showcase for yet another brilliant performance.

Cast: Tobey Maguire, Kirsten Dunst, James Franco, Alfred Molina
CriticsConsensus: Boasting an entertaining villain and deeper emotional focus, this is a nimble sequel that improves upon the original.

MovieTitle: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
Cast: Elijah Wood, Ian McKellen, Liv Tyler, Viggo Mortensen
CriticsConsensus: Visually breathtaking and emotionally powerful,  The Lord of the Rings - The Return of the King is a moving and satisfying conclusion to a great trilogy.

Cast: Adam Sandler, Ben Stiller, Dustin Hoffman, Emma Thompson
CriticsConsensus: The Meyerowitz Stories (New and Selected) observes the family dynamic through writer-director Noah Baumbach's bittersweet lens and the impressive efforts of a remarkable cast.

Cast: Adam Sandler, Juancho Hernangomez, Queen Latifah, Ben Foster
CriticsConsensus: Hustle doesn't have any fancy moves, but it doesn't need them -- Adam Sandler's everyman charm makes this easy layup fun to watch.

Cast: Madeline Brewer, Patch Darragh, Melora Walters, Devin Druid
CriticsConsensus: Smart and suspenseful, CAM is a techno-thriller that's far more than the sum of its salacious parts -- and an outstanding showcase for Madeline Brewer in the leading role.

Cast: John Gallagher Jr., Kate Siegel, Michael Trucco, Samantha Sloyan
CriticsConsensus: Hush navigates the bloody waters of home invasion thrillers and incisive slashers for a contemporary horror puree.

Cast: Lamis Ammar, Ruba Blal, Hitham Omari, Khadija Al Akel
CriticsConsensus: Sand Storm marks an impressive first feature for debuting writer-director Elite Zexer that offers a perceptive -- and crucial -- look at patriarchal traditions.

MovieTitle: Glass Onion: A Knives Out Mystery
Cast: Daniel Craig, Ed Norton, Dave Bautista, Kate Hudson
CriticsConsensus: Glass Onion: A Knives Out Mystery brings back Benoit Blanc for another wildly entertaining mystery rounded out by an outstanding ensemble cast.

Cast: Daniel Craig, Judi Dench, Javier Bardem, Ralph Fiennes
CriticsConsensus: Sam Mendes brings Bond surging back with a smart, sexy, riveting action thriller that qualifies as one of the best 007 films to date.

Cast: Delroy Lindo, Jonathan Majors, Clarke Peters, Norm Lewis
CriticsConsensus: Fierce energy and ambition course through Da 5 Bloods, coming together to fuel one of Spike Lee's most urgent and impactful films.

Cast: Christian Bale, Bradley Cooper, Jeremy Renner, Amy Adams
CriticsConsensus: Riotously funny and impeccably cast, American Hustle compensates for its flaws with unbridled energy and some of David O. Russell's most irrepressibly vibrant direction.

Cast: Matt Damon, Julia Stiles, Joan Allen, David Strathairn
CriticsConsensus: The Bourne Ultimatum is an intelligent, finely tuned non-stop thrill ride. Another strong performance from Matt Damon and sharp camerawork from Paul Greengrass make this the finest installment of the Bourne trilogy.

MovieTitle: El Camino: A Breaking Bad Movie
Cast: Aaron Paul, Matt L. Jones, Charles Baker
CriticsConsensus: Entertaining if not essential, El Camino adds a satisfying belated coda to the Breaking Bad story -- led by a career-best performance from Aaron Paul.

Cast: Raúl Castillo, Sheila Vand, Evan Rosado, Isaiah Kristian
CriticsConsensus: Dreamlike and haunting, We the Animals approaches the coming-of-age odyssey with a uniquely documentarian eye.

Cast: Jeff Bridges, Rachel McAdams, James Franco, Marion Cotillard
CriticsConsensus: Beautifully animated and faithful to the spirit of its classic source material, The Little Prince is a family-friendly treat that anchors thrilling visuals with a satisfying story.

Cast: Alisha Weir, Emma Thompson, Lashana Lynch, Stephen Graham
CriticsConsensus: Roald Dahl's Matilda the Musical brings the classic story back to the screen with a delightful Emma Thompson, dazzling dancing, and a suitably irascible take on the source material.

Cast: Sylvester Stallone, Talia Shire, Burgess Meredith, Burt Young
CriticsConsensus: This story of a down-on-his-luck boxer is thoroughly predictable, but Sylvester Stallone's script and stunning performance in the title role brush aside complaints.

Cast: Zoey Deutch, Glen Powell, Lucy Liu, Taye Diggs
CriticsConsensus: Set It Up follows the long-established outlines of the rom-com template -- and in the process, proves there's still substantial pleasure to be wrought from familiar formulas.

Cast: Steve Martin, Mary Steenburgen, Dianne Wiest, Jason Robards
CriticsConsensus: Bolstered by a delightful cast, Parenthood is a funny and thoughtfully crafted look at the best and worst moments of family life that resonates broadly.

Cast: Julian Barratt, Essie Davis, Andrea Riseborough, Harriet Walter
CriticsConsensus: Led by a committed performance from Julian Barratt, Mindhorn offers audiences a laugh-out-loud comedy whose sublime silliness is enhanced by its more thoughtful moments.

Cast: Thomas Jane, Neal McDonough, Molly Parker, Brian d'Arcy James
CriticsConsensus: Thanks to director Zak Hilditch's patient storytelling and strong work from lead Thomas Jane, 1922 ranks among the more satisfying Stephen King adaptations.

Cast: Mamoudou Athie, Courtney B. Vance, Niecy Nash, Sasha Compère
CriticsConsensus: Like a good wine, once you let Uncorked breathe, its heartfelt tenderness will yield a sweet time.

Cast: Ryan Gosling, Emma Stone, John Legend, Rosemarie DeWitt
CriticsConsensus: La La Land breathes new life into a bygone genre with thrillingly assured direction, powerful performances, and an irresistible excess of heart.

Cast: Daniel Day-Lewis, Vicky Krieps, Lesley Manville, Camilla Rutherford
CriticsConsensus: Phantom Thread's finely woven narrative is filled out nicely by humor, intoxicating romantic tension, and yet another impressively committed performance from Daniel Day-Lewis.

Cast: Russell Crowe, Ryan Gosling, Angourie Rice, Matt Bomer
CriticsConsensus: The Nice Guys hearkens back to the buddy comedies of a bygone era while adding something extra courtesy of a knowing script and the irresistible chemistry of its leads.

Cast: Jessica Chastain, Jason Clarke, Joel Edgerton, Jennifer Ehle
CriticsConsensus: Gripping, suspenseful, and brilliantly crafted, Zero Dark Thirty dramatizes the hunt for Osama bin Laden with intelligence and an eye for detail.

MovieTitle: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
Cast: Elijah Wood, Ian McKellen, Liv Tyler, Viggo Mortensen
CriticsConsensus: Full of eye-popping special effects, and featuring a pitch-perfect cast, The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring brings J.R.R. Tolkien's classic to vivid life.

Cast: Judi Dench, Steve Coogan, Michelle Fairley, Barbara Jefford
CriticsConsensus: Based on a powerful true story and led by note-perfect performances from Judi Dench and Steve Coogan, Philomena offers a profoundly affecting drama for adult filmgoers of all ages.

Cast: Adarsh Gourav, Rajkummar Rao, Priyanka Chopra Jonas, Vedant Sinha
CriticsConsensus: Well-acted and beautifully made, The White Tiger distills the strengths of its source material into a grimly compelling drama.

Cast: Idris Elba, Abraham Attah, Opeyemi Fagbohungbe, Kurt Egyiawan
CriticsConsensus: Beasts of No Nation finds writer-director Cary Fukunaga working with a talented cast to offer a sobering, uncompromising, yet still somehow hopeful picture of war's human cost.

Cast: André Holland, Zazie Beetz, Bill Duke, Sonja Sohn
CriticsConsensus: High Flying Bird takes a thoughtful and engrossing look at professional sports that sees Steven Soderbergh continuing to test the limits of new filmmaking technology.

Cast: Jack Black, Bill Wise, Lee Eddy, Milo Coy
CriticsConsensus: The sweetly nostalgic Apollo 10 1/2: A Space Age Childhood finds Richard Linklater reusing visual and thematic ingredients in a deeply personal, freshly inspired way.

Cast: Adriano Tardiolo, Alba Rohrwacher, Agnese Graziani, Tommaso Ragno
CriticsConsensus: Happy as Lazzaro uses a friendship's ups and downs as a satisfyingly expansive canvas for a picture rich with thematic and cinematic depth.

Cast: Matthew Modine, Adam Baldwin, Vincent D'Onofrio, R. Lee Ermey
CriticsConsensus: Intense, tightly constructed, and darkly comic at times, Stanley Kubrick's Full Metal Jacket may not boast the most original of themes, but it is exceedingly effective at communicating them.

Cast: Carla Gugino, Bruce Greenwood, Henry Thomas, Carel Struycken
CriticsConsensus: Carla Gugino carries Gerald's Game's small-scale suspense with a career-defining performance.

Cast: Billy Crystal, Meg Ryan, Carrie Fisher, Bruno Kirby
CriticsConsensus: Rob Reiner's touching, funny film set a new standard for romantic comedies, and he was ably abetted by the sharp interplay between Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan.

Cast: Will Forte, Maya Rudolph, Alessia Cara, Terry Crews
CriticsConsensus: An appealing animated adventure whose silliness is anchored in genuine emotion, The Willoughbys offers fanciful fun the entire family can enjoy.

Cast: John Belushi, Kevin Bacon, Donald Sutherland, Karen Allen
CriticsConsensus: The talents of director John Landis and Saturday Night Live's irrepressible John Belushi conspired to create a rambunctious, subversive college comedy that continues to resonate.

Cast: George Clooney, Vera Farmiga, Anna Kendrick, Jason Bateman
CriticsConsensus: Led by charismatic performances by its three leads, director Jason Reitman delivers a smart blend of humor and emotion with just enough edge for mainstream audiences.

Cast: Benedict Cumberbatch, Keira Knightley, Matthew Goode, Rory Kinnear
CriticsConsensus: With an outstanding starring performance from Benedict Cumberbatch illuminating its fact-based story, The Imitation Game serves as an eminently well-made entry in the "prestige biopic" genre.

Cast: Tom Cruise, Colin Farrell, Samantha Morton, Max von Sydow
CriticsConsensus: Thought-provoking and visceral, Steven Spielberg successfully combines high concept ideas and high octane action in this fast and febrile sci-fi thriller.

Cast: Tobey Maguire, Willem Dafoe, Kirsten Dunst, James Franco
CriticsConsensus: Not only does Spider-Man provide a good dose of web-swinging fun, it also has a heart, thanks to the combined charms of director Sam Raimi and star Tobey Maguire.

Cast: Jonathan Pryce, Anthony Hopkins, Juan Minujín, Sidney Cole
CriticsConsensus: Led by outstanding performances from its well-matched leads, The Two Popes draws absorbing drama from a pivotal moment in modern organized religion.

Cast: Maggie Gyllenhaal, Gael García Bernal, Michael Chernus, Anna Baryshnikov
CriticsConsensus: Elevated by a bravura performance from Maggie Gyllenhaal, The Kindergarten Teacher is one American remake that retains its impact the second time around.

Cast: Harvey Keitel, Tim Roth, Michael Madsen, Chris Penn
CriticsConsensus: Thrumming with intelligence and energy, Reservoir Dogs opens Quentin Tarantino's filmmaking career with hard-hitting style.

Cast: Géza Morcsányi, Alexandra Borbély, Zoltán Schneider, Ervin Nagy
CriticsConsensus: Tender performances and a strong sense of style combine to create an eccentric, dreamy portrait of love and loneliness in On Body and Soul.

Cast: Clint Eastwood, Meryl Streep, Annie Corley, Victor Slezak
CriticsConsensus: Sentimental, slow, schmaltzy, and very satisfying, The Bridges of Madison County finds Clint Eastwood adapting a bestseller with heft, wit, and grace.

Cast: Eddie Redmayne, Alex Sharp, Sacha Baron Cohen, Jeremy Strong
CriticsConsensus: An actors' showcase enlivened by its topical fact-based story, The Trial of the Chicago 7 plays squarely -- and compellingly -- to Aaron Sorkin's strengths.

Cast: Woody Harrelson, Jesse Eisenberg, Emma Stone, Abigail Breslin
CriticsConsensus: Wickedly funny and featuring plenty of gore, Zombieland is proof that the zombie subgenre is far from dead.

Cast: Tim Blake Nelson, Willie Watson, David Krumholtz, James Franco
CriticsConsensus: The Ballad of Buster Scruggs avoids anthology pitfalls with a consistent collection tied together by the Coen brothers' signature blend of dark drama and black humor.

MovieTitle: All Quiet on the Western Front
Cast: Felix Kammerer, Albrecht Schuch, Aaron Hilmer, Moritz Klaus
CriticsConsensus: Both timely and timeless, All Quiet on the Western Front retains the power of its classic source material by focusing on the futility of war.

Cast: Ali Wong, Randall Park, Keanu Reeves, Michelle Buteau
CriticsConsensus: Carried by the infectious charms of Ali Wong and Randall Park, Always Be My Maybe takes familiar rom-com beats and cleverly layers in smart social commentary to find its own sweet groove.

Cast: Hilary Swank, Clara Rugaard, Rose Byrne, Tahlia Sturzaker
CriticsConsensus: Suspenseful, well-acted, and intelligent, I Am Mother is an ambitious sci-fi story that largely achieves its impressive aims.

MovieTitle: I Don't Feel at Home in This World Anymore
Cast: Melanie Lynskey, Elijah Wood, David Yow, Jane Levy
CriticsConsensus: I don't feel at home in this world anymore. transcends its unwieldy title to offer timely, intoxicatingly dark observations on gender dynamics and social norms in modern America.

Cast: Mark Duplass, Ray Romano, Marguerite Moreau, Christine Woods
CriticsConsensus: It takes its time coming together, but the quietly effective Paddleton pulls off a tricky tonal balancing act, thanks largely to the strengths of its well-chosen leads.

Cast: Johnny Depp, Isla Fisher, Abigail Breslin, Ned Beatty
CriticsConsensus: Rango is a smart, giddily creative burst of beautifully animated entertainment, and Johnny Depp gives a colorful vocal performance as a household pet in an unfamiliar world.

Cast: Sam Rockwell, Zazie Beetz, Marc Maron, Awkwafina
CriticsConsensus: Fast-paced, funny, and full of colorful visual appeal, The Bad Guys is good news for audiences seeking options the whole family can enjoy.

Cast: Shameik Moore, Tony Revolori, Kiersey Clemons, Kimberly Elise
CriticsConsensus: Featuring a starmaking performance from Shameik Moore and a refreshingly original point of view from writer-director Rick Famuyiwa, Dope is smart, insightful entertainment.

Cast: Mélanie Laurent, Mathieu Amalric, Malik Zidi, Marc Saez
CriticsConsensus: Oxygen gets the white-knuckle maximum out of its claustrophobic setting, with director Alexandre Aja and star Mélanie Laurent making this a must-watch thriller for sci-fi fans.

Cast: Kiana Madeira, Ashley Zukerman, Gillian Jacobs, Olivia Welch
CriticsConsensus: Fear Street Part Three: 1666 sends the slasher series back in time for a trilogy-concluding installment that caps things off on a screaming high note.

Cast: Al Pacino, Johnny Depp, Michael Madsen, Bruno Kirby
CriticsConsensus: A stark, nuanced portrait of life in organized crime, bolstered by strong performances from Al Pacino and Johnny Depp.

Cast: Leonardo DiCaprio, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Elliot Page, Tom Hardy
CriticsConsensus: Smart, innovative, and thrilling, Inception is that rare summer blockbuster that succeeds viscerally as well as intellectually.

Cast: Kevin Spacey, Annette Bening, Thora Birch, Wes Bentley
CriticsConsensus: Flawlessly cast and brimming with dark, acid wit, American Beauty is a smart, provocative high point of late '90s mainstream Hollywood film.

Cast: Jack Black, Angelina Jolie, Jackie Chan, David Cross
CriticsConsensus: Kung Fu Panda has a familiar message, but the pleasing mix of humor, swift martial arts action, and colorful animation makes for winning Summer entertainment.
